content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Anne Mullins: Well, I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and I've lived in the state most of my life, though I moved around a bit as a kid. My father passed away when I was just ten years old, which was really hard on my family. My mother worked multiple jobs to keep us afloat, and she always made sure we had what we needed, even if it wasn't much. I grew up in a small, tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other, and I remember playing outside until the streetlights came on every evening. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books than in sports or socializing. I guess that's why I ended up going to college — I wanted to learn as much as I could and maybe find a way to make a better life for myself. I got my bachelor's degree in business administration, which wasn't exactly what I had in mind at first, but it ended up being a good fit. I met my husband, Tom, while I was working part-time at a local bookstore, and we've been married for over ten years now. We have two kids, a boy and a girl, and we live in the same house I grew up in, though it's been remodeled a bit. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've always tried to keep a positive outlook and make the best of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Anne Mullins: There was definitely a crossroads in my life, and it came right after my father passed away. I was only ten, and I remember feeling like the world had shifted beneath my feet. My mother was strong, but she was also exhausted, working two jobs just to keep the lights on. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, watching her cry quietly after she got home from her second shift, and I realized that if I wanted to change our situation, I had to take responsibility. I decided then that I would work hard in school, not just for myself but for her. I didn't know what I wanted to be when I grew up, but I knew I didn't want to end up in the same place we were. That decision led me to focus on my studies, and eventually, I got a scholarship to a local community college. I remember feeling so proud when I walked across that stage to receive my bachelor's degree — it felt like I was finally paying back the sacrifices my mother made. That moment defined who I am today: someone who believes in hard work, resilience, and the power of education to change your life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Anne Mullins: I think it was a conscious choice, even if I didn't realize it at the time. I remember sitting there at that kitchen table, watching my mom struggle, and I felt this deep sense of responsibility. I didn't have a lot of options, but I knew I had to make something of myself. I didn't just decide to work hard — I decided to take control of my future. I remember telling my mom that night, 'I'm going to make sure you don't have to work this hard anymore.' It wasn't just a promise to myself, it was a promise to her. And I think that's what made the difference. I didn't just drift — I chose a path, and I stuck to it, even when it was hard.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Anne Mullins: Absolutely, I think help could have made a difference, but I also think it's easy to feel like you have to rely on yourself when you're in a tough spot. My mom didn't ask for help — she was too proud, and I think I felt the same way. But looking back, I wish we had reached out more. There were programs at the school for kids who had lost a parent, and maybe that could have given me more support. I remember one teacher who noticed I was quiet and offered to help me with my homework after school. That small act of kindness meant a lot. I think if more people had seen us and offered a hand, it might have made things a little easier. But I also know that even without that help, I had the strength to push through — and I'm proud of that too.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Anne Mullins: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Tom, and I met at that local bookstore I mentioned earlier — he was a part-time manager there, and I was working the cash register. We connected over our shared love of books and music, and it wasn't long before we started dating. We got married when I was 28, and shortly after, we had our first child, a son named Liam. A few years later, our daughter, Claire, came along. They're both wonderful kids — Liam is into sports and has a passion for photography, while Claire is more of a bookworm like me. We live in the same house I grew up in, which feels like a full circle in some ways. It's not perfect, but it's our home, and we've built a lot of memories there. Tom and I both work full-time, and while it's busy, we try to make time for each other and for the kids. I think the most important thing is that we're all in this together, and we support each other through the ups and downs of life.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's interesting to look back at the challenges I faced as a child, especially after my father passed away, and see how they shaped the person I am today. I never imagined that moment at the kitchen table would lead me to the life I have now with my husband, Tom, and our two kids. I'm proud of the choices I made, even when it wasn't easy, and I'm grateful for the small acts of kindness I received along the way. It's also humbling to think about how much support I could have used but didn't ask for — I hope I can be that kind of support for others now. Overall, these questions reminded me of the power of resilience, education, and love in building a life that, while not perfect, is deeply meaningful.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Anne Mullins: My immediate family includes my mother, Margaret, and my younger brother, Sean. My mom has always been my rock — even though she didn't ask for help, she gave me everything she could, and I know she's proud of the life I've built. We don't see each other as often as I'd like because she moved to a smaller town in the same state after she retired, but whenever we do get together, it's like no time has passed. Sean is ten years younger than me, and while we had our share of sibling rivalry growing up, we're close now. He's a mechanic and has a family of his own — two kids and a wife who's a nurse. We keep in touch, and I love hearing about his life. He always says I was the one who made it out, but I tell him he's got his own path to walk. Family is important to me, and even though we've all taken different roads, I know we're all trying to do the best we can.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Anne Mullins: There are a few friends who have been important to me over the years — people who have stood by me through good times and bad. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same business class, and even though I was pretty quiet back then, she always made sure to include me in conversations. She became one of my closest friends, and even after we graduated, we stayed in touch. She ended up moving to Chicago for a job, but we still talk regularly. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for that management position at the bookstore, which eventually led to meeting Tom. Then there's my neighbor, Linda, who's been like a second mother to me. She's always had my back, whether it was helping me with the kids or just listening when I needed someone to talk to. I think the people who matter most in life are the ones who show up, even when things are tough — and I'm lucky to have a few of them in my corner.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Anne Mullins: I live in a neighborhood that's a mix of old and new — some of the houses are over a hundred years old, with those classic Iowa porches and big front yards, while others are newer developments with modern touches. It's a quiet place, not too far from the city center but still with that small-town feel. There's a park right down the street where the kids play, and a few local shops that have been around for decades. I love that sense of community here — people wave when they see you, and if you're ever in a bind, someone will always offer a hand. It's not perfect, of course — like anywhere, there are challenges — but it feels like a place where people care about each other. I think that's why I chose to stay here, even after I had the chance to move somewhere bigger. This neighborhood has been part of my life for so long, and it feels like home, even with all its quirks.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Anne Mullins: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of familiarity and trust that comes with living in the same neighborhood for so long. I know most of the people who walk these streets, and they know me. If something were ever wrong, I think someone would be on my doorstep before I even had a chance to call for help. That said, I'm not naive — there are always risks in any place, but I think the strong community ties here make a big difference. I've seen neighbors look out for each other, especially when someone is going through a tough time. It's not just about safety; it's about feeling like you belong, and that makes you feel secure in a way that nothing else can.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Anne Mullins: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The good thing is, I've always felt a sense of belonging here. There are days when I get frustrated with the slow pace or the occasional inconvenience — like the time the city tried to redo the roads and it took six months to finish — but I've learned to roll with it. The downside is that sometimes the same small-town feel that makes me feel safe can also feel a little insular. There are people who don't always understand the struggles of someone who grew up in a less-than-ideal situation, and I've had to learn how to set boundaries when I need to. But overall, I think the positives outweigh the negatives. I love the sense of history here, the way the seasons change so clearly, and the fact that my kids are growing up in a place that feels like home. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that matters more than anything.

Going through the recent interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings about the life I've built. Talking about my husband, Tom, and our kids made me realize how much I value the stability and love we've created together. It's amazing how far I've come from the quiet girl at the kitchen table, watching my mom struggle, to the woman who now has a family of her own. When I described our neighborhood, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the community that has supported me through the years — people like Linda and Sarah who have been there for me when I needed them most. And when I reflected on feeling safe here, it reminded me of how much I've learned to trust not just the place, but the people in it. It's not just about the house I live in or the streets I walk — it's about the connections, the history, and the love that make this place feel like home.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Anne Mullins: A typical week for me is pretty full, but it's also pretty balanced. I work full-time at a local accounting firm, which means I'm usually in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. My job is pretty routine, but I enjoy the structure and the challenge of keeping things organized. On weekdays, I drop the kids off at school before heading to work, and I try to have lunch with them at least once a week — usually on Fridays, when I pick them up early. After work, I pick them up, and we have dinner together as a family. On weekends, it's a bit different — Tom and I usually take the kids to the park or to a local museum, or we have friends over for dinner. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading a book or just sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee and watching the neighborhood kids play. It's not always perfect, but I think that balance is what keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Anne Mullins: I work as an accountant at a local firm, and I'm usually in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. It's a steady job, which is good because it gives me the structure I need to balance everything else in my life. I've been there for about six years now, and I actually enjoy the work — it's challenging in its own way, but I find satisfaction in making sure things run smoothly for the clients we serve. I started out as an assistant, and over time, I worked my way up to a senior accountant position. It's not the most exciting job in the world, but it pays the bills and allows me to be there for my family. I also do some freelance work on the side, mostly helping small businesses with their taxes during tax season. It's extra income, but it also keeps my skills sharp and gives me a sense of purpose outside of my regular job.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Anne Mullins: Outside of work and family, I have a few other routines that keep me grounded. Every Sunday evening, I like to sit down with my journal and write a few pages about the week that just passed. It's not always about big events — sometimes it's just about the little things, like the way the sun sets over the park or how my daughter laughed at something I said. It helps me process everything and reminds me of how far we've come. I also take care of my mother's garden when she's not around, which is something we used to do together when I was a kid. It feels like a way to stay connected to her, even when we're not physically together. And on the weekends, I try to get out of the house as much as possible — whether it's a hike, a visit to the library, or just a coffee with a friend. Life can get busy, but I think it's important to make time for the things that bring you peace and joy — even if it's just a few minutes here and there.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Anne Mullins: Well, the biggest change to my daily routine has been adjusting to my kids growing up and starting to have more responsibilities of their own. Liam, my son, is now in high school, and he's taking on more of the chores at home, like helping with the laundry and even cooking simple meals sometimes. It's amazing to see him becoming more independent — it's both exciting and a little bittersweet. Claire, on the other hand, is in middle school, and she's started to get more involved in extracurricular activities, like the school drama club. That means more evenings spent at practices or performances, which has shifted our family dinner time a bit. I've had to be more flexible with my schedule, sometimes working from home a couple of days a week to help out with the kids' needs. It's not been without its challenges, but I think it's a natural part of life — watching them grow and learning to let go a little more. It's also given me more time to focus on my own goals, like finally taking that painting class I've been wanting to try for years. Life keeps changing, and I'm trying to keep up — one brushstroke at a time.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Anne Mullins: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts pretty early. Liam, my son, is up at 6:30 a.m. to get ready for school, and he usually grabs a quick breakfast before heading out. He's on the school's soccer team, so he has practice after school most days, and he's also involved in the yearbook club. Claire, my daughter, gets up a little later — around 7 a.m. — and she usually has a more leisurely breakfast with me before heading off to school. She's in the drama club, so she has rehearsals a couple of times a week, and she also takes piano lessons on Thursdays. After school, they both come home, grab a snack, and do their homework. I try to be there to help them when I can, but they're both pretty independent now. On days when Liam has soccer practice, we usually have dinner a bit later, and sometimes we'll go out for a bite to eat at one of the local restaurants. Claire's drama club performances are on weekends, so those days are a bit more chaotic, but it's all part of growing up. I love seeing them get involved in things they're passionate about — it makes me feel like I'm watching my own dreams come true through them.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, yet how deeply rooted I still feel in the place and people that shaped me. Talking about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines reminded me of the balance I've worked so hard to create — between responsibility and joy, between the past and the present. It's incredible how the quiet girl at the kitchen table, watching her mother struggle, has grown into a woman who now has her own family, a stable career, and a strong sense of community. I've come to appreciate the small routines that keep me grounded — like journaling on Sundays or tending to my mother's garden — and I realize how much they help me process the bigger picture of my life. The changes in my kids' routines and their growing independence also remind me that life is a constant flow, and while it can be bittersweet, it's also a beautiful journey. I feel grateful for the support I've received over the years and hope to pass that same sense of care and resilience on to my children and others in my community.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Anne Mullins: As for my health, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape overall, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I used to be pretty active as a kid — I remember running around the neighborhood with my friends, climbing trees, and even trying to keep up with my brother when he was younger. But as I got older, life got busier, and I didn't always make time for exercise the way I should have. A few years ago, I started feeling the effects of that — I was always tired, and I noticed I wasn't as energetic as I used to be. That's when I decided to make some changes. I started going for walks with the kids after school, and I even joined a yoga class at the community center a couple of times a week. It's not perfect — some days I'm more consistent than others — but I've noticed a difference. I feel more balanced, both physically and mentally. I also try to eat as healthily as I can, even if it's not always easy with two kids and a busy work schedule. I've learned to listen to my body more, and I think that's been the biggest shift. I'm not saying I'm in perfect health — I still get the occasional cold or ache — but I'm grateful for the little things, like being able to keep up with my kids on a hike or feeling strong enough to carry groceries without breaking a sweat. Health, I've come to realize, isn't about being perfect — it's about making choices that help you live your life to the fullest, even when it's not easy.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Anne Mullins: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having the support of my family and the small habits I've managed to build over time. The kids have started joining me on my walks, and it's become a bonding moment for us — we talk about their day, laugh about the silly things that happen, and it's a way to disconnect from the chaos of school and work. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling act. There are days when I'm so caught up in work deadlines or helping with homework that I forget to eat properly or take a break. I also struggle with staying consistent when the weather is bad or when I'm just too tired after a long day. It's not about perfection — it's about showing up, even if it's just for ten minutes of yoga or a quick walk around the block. I've learned that small, consistent choices matter more than trying to do everything at once. And honestly, knowing that I'm setting an example for my kids is what keeps me going — I want them to see that taking care of yourself is just as important as taking care of others.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Anne Mullins: In the past two years, I actually had a minor health scare that reminded me how important it is to take care of myself. I started experiencing some persistent back pain, which I initially dismissed as just stress or poor posture from sitting at my desk too long. But after a few months of it getting worse, I finally made an appointment with a doctor. Turns out, I had a herniated disc in my lower back. It wasn't anything too serious, but it did require some physical therapy and a few weeks of adjusting my routine. I was pretty grateful that it wasn't something worse, but it was a wake-up call. I realized I had been pushing through pain for a while without really listening to my body. Since then, I've been more careful about how I sit, stand, and lift things — and I've made a point to take more breaks throughout the day. I also started seeing a physical therapist twice a week, and it's been helping a lot. It's funny, though — I think the experience made me more in tune with my health in a way I wasn't before. I used to think I was doing okay just by showing up every day, but now I know that showing up in a healthy way matters just as much.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Anne Mullins: Honestly, the back pain did make things a bit more challenging, especially with the demands of work and taking care of the kids. There were days when I had to cancel meetings or take a break from grading papers because I was just too sore. I remember one afternoon when I was trying to help Liam with his homework and my back flared up so badly that I had to sit on the floor for a while just to catch my breath. It was humbling, to be honest — I used to think I was pretty tough, but that moment reminded me that my body has limits. What's funny is that it also brought my family closer. Tom started helping with more of the household tasks, and the kids learned to be more mindful of how I was feeling. It wasn't easy, but it taught me that health isn't just about being strong — it's about knowing when to slow down and ask for help. I think that's something I want to pass on to my kids, too — that it's okay to take care of yourself, even if it means saying 'no' to something for a while.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Anne Mullins: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions — mostly gratitude, but also a deep sense of growth. It's been a year of transitions, both for me and for my family. Watching Liam take on more responsibility at home and in school has been incredible. He's becoming more confident, and I see pieces of myself in him — that same quiet determination, even if he's more outgoing than I was. Claire, on the other hand, has been navigating the ups and downs of middle school, which has been both challenging and rewarding. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed, especially with work and keeping up with their schedules, but I've also felt a sense of pride in how they're growing into their own people. I've also been focusing more on my own well-being, which has been a journey in itself. I started that painting class I mentioned earlier, and it's been a beautiful way to express myself and slow down. There were days when I felt like I wasn't doing enough, but I've learned to be kinder to myself and celebrate the small victories. Overall, I feel like I'm in a good place — not perfect, but grounded, and I'm grateful for the people and moments that have brought me here.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my life has changed in the past few years, especially as my children grow and my own health becomes something I have to pay more attention to. It's amazing to see Liam taking on more responsibilities and Claire diving into her passions — it's both exciting and a little bittersweet. At the same time, dealing with my back pain was a wake-up call. I used to think I could push through anything, but that experience taught me the importance of listening to my body and taking care of myself, even when it's hard. It's not just about being strong — it's about knowing when to slow down and ask for help. I'm grateful for the support of my family and the small habits I've built, like walking with the kids or taking time for myself with painting. Life is constantly changing, and I'm learning to embrace the journey, even when it's messy or uncomfortable.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Anne Mullins: I think I've had my share of moments where I felt overwhelmed or down, especially during the hardest times in my life — like after my father passed away or when I was juggling school, work, and taking care of my mom. But I don't think I'd call it depression or anxiety in the way some people describe it. For me, it's more about the quiet weight of responsibility and the pressure to keep going, even when things feel heavy. I remember there were days when I just wanted to sit in the kitchen and not move, but I had to push through for my family. Over the years, I've learned to recognize when I'm feeling that way and find little ways to cope — like journaling, talking to a friend, or just taking a walk. I think the biggest thing is that I've come to accept that it's okay to not be okay all the time. I've also started seeing a counselor once a month, just to check in and make sure I'm not carrying too much. It's not about being broken — it's about being human and learning how to take care of yourself along the way.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Anne Mullins: For my family, it's been a year of adjusting to new rhythms and learning how to support each other in different ways. Tom has been amazing — he's taken on more of the household responsibilities, especially when I was dealing with my back pain, and he's always been there to listen when I need to talk. The kids, too, have grown so much. Liam is starting to see himself as more of a leader, not just at home but also with his friends, and I love seeing that confidence in him. Claire has been navigating the emotional rollercoaster of middle school, and while it's been tough at times, she's also discovered her voice in ways I never expected — like when she stood up for a friend during a tough situation. It's been a year of learning patience, of letting go a little, and of finding new ways to connect. I think we've all come out of it stronger, even if it wasn't always easy.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Anne Mullins: When it comes to religion or spirituality, I think I fall somewhere in between — not strictly tied to any one belief system, but deeply connected to the idea of finding meaning in life's small moments. I was raised Catholic, and I still respect the traditions and values that shaped me, especially the emphasis on compassion and community. But over the years, I've come to see spirituality more as a personal journey than something defined by doctrine. I find peace in things like nature, in the quiet moments with my family, and in the way life keeps unfolding, even when it's messy. I don't go to church regularly anymore, but I do light a candle on my kitchen table every Sunday, just like my mother used to. It's a small gesture, but it reminds me of where I came from and the strength it took to get here. I think spirituality, for me, is about being present — being grateful for the people in my life, for the lessons I've learned, and for the resilience that keeps me moving forward, even when I don't have all the answers.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Anne Mullins: To be honest, I don't use social media very much — it's not that I dislike it, but I've always found more joy in the real, face-to-face connections than in scrolling through screens. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with family and old friends, and I'll occasionally post a photo of the kids or a garden update if I feel like sharing. I used to be more active online when I was in college, but over time, I realized how much more meaningful my relationships became when I wasn't constantly comparing my life to others'. I do follow a few pages about gardening and local community events, just to stay connected to the things I care about. It's not a big part of my life, but I'm grateful for the ways it helps me stay in touch with people who matter. I think I've learned that being present in the moment — whether it's with my family, in nature, or just sitting quietly with a book — is where I find the most peace.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Anne Mullins: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for emotional or financial support — not in the way some people do. I know it can be a lifeline for others, especially when they're going through something tough and need to connect with people who understand. But for me, support has always come from the people I know in real life, the ones who show up when it matters. That said, I do appreciate the way Facebook has helped me stay in touch with friends and family, especially those who live far away. I remember a time when my mom was going through a tough health scare, and I was able to share updates with her friends and cousins who had moved away. It was comforting to know they were thinking of her, even if they couldn't be there in person. I guess I see social media more as a tool for staying connected rather than a source of support. But I can see how it might be different for someone else — I just haven't needed it that way in my own life.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health has become a part of my daily life and how it's shaped the way I see myself and my responsibilities. Talking about my herniated disc and the physical therapy I've been undergoing reminded me of how fragile and resilient the body can be. It's humbling to realize that even someone who used to think they could push through anything has limits, and that's okay. It also made me think about how my health challenges have affected my family — how Tom has stepped up, how the kids have learned to be more mindful of my needs, and how I've had to adjust my routines to make space for healing. It's not just about the pain or the diagnosis — it's about the lessons I've learned along the way, like the importance of asking for help, slowing down, and taking care of myself so I can be there for the people I love. I'm still figuring it out, but I'm grateful for the journey and the growing awareness that health is not just about being strong — it's about being present, both for myself and for those who depend on me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Anne Mullins: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted — not necessarily less, but more manageable. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of everything on my own, especially with work, the kids, and my health. But I've started to lean more into the coping strategies that have helped me before, like journaling and spending time in nature. I also found that talking to Tom more openly about my feelings has made a huge difference. I used to think I had to handle everything quietly, but now I see that vulnerability isn't a weakness — it's a way to connect and grow. I've also started practicing mindfulness, even if it's just for a few minutes each morning. It's not always easy, but I've come to realize that stress isn't something to be eliminated — it's something to be acknowledged and worked with. I'm learning to take a breath when things feel overwhelming, to remind myself that I'm doing the best I can, and that it's okay to not have all the answers. I think that's the biggest change — I'm more patient with myself now, and that has made all the difference.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Anne Mullins: Last month, our biggest expenses were definitely the kids' school-related costs — things like supplies, extracurricular fees, and transportation. Liam's soccer team had a season pass and some equipment costs, and Claire's drama club had a few performance fees and costume expenses. Then there's the mortgage, of course, and utilities, which always seem to add up, especially with the heating and cooling costs in Iowa. Groceries are another big one — with two kids and a family of four, it's easy to spend more than you expect. I also had some out-of-pocket medical costs from my physical therapy sessions, which I'm grateful for but also a bit stressful when you're trying to balance everything. To make ends meet, I've been careful with our budget — we stick to meal planning, buy in bulk when we can, and I've been doing some freelance work on the side to help cover unexpected costs. It's not always easy, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most and find creative ways to stretch every dollar. It's a balancing act, but I'm proud of how we've managed to keep things stable, even with all the changes in our lives.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Anne Mullins: Last month, our household spent just under $4,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, we hover around $4,000 to $4,200 a month. The increase was mostly due to the kids' school activities — Liam's soccer season and Claire's drama club performances added up, and I had to cover some unexpected costs for his physical therapy sessions. We also had a few car maintenance bills come up, which I hadn't budgeted for. But I've learned to be flexible — we cut back on non-essentials like dining out and entertainment, and I've been doing more freelance work to make up the difference. It's not always easy, but I've come to see budgeting as part of the journey — not just about numbers, but about making choices that reflect what matters most to us as a family.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Anne Mullins: We own our home — it's the same house I grew up in, actually. It's a bit of a sentimental thing for me, but it also makes sense financially. Renting would have been more expensive in the long run, especially with the way property values have gone up in Des Moines. We've made a few upgrades over the years, like adding a new roof and updating the kitchen, but for the most part, it's still the same house with the same creaky floors and the big front porch where I used to sit with my mom after school. It's not perfect, but it's ours, and that means a lot. I think owning a home has given me a sense of stability, especially as my kids are growing up. It's a place they can call their own, and it's also a reminder of how far we've come — from that small, struggling family to a home filled with laughter, books, and the occasional soccer ball flying through the yard.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Anne Mullins: Over the past year, our bills have definitely had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what was going on with the kids. In the winter, heating costs always spike, and we had a particularly cold spell last January that made the bill jump by a couple hundred dollars. Then there's the summer — we use a lot of electricity for air conditioning, and with the kids' summer camps and activities, we ended up spending more on supplies and transportation. Holidays are another big one — we try to keep it simple, but there's always the cost of gifts, decorations, and maybe a family dinner out. School starts and ends also affect our budget — when the kids are in school full-time, we spend more on meals and extracurriculars, but when they're out for summer break, we save a bit on transportation and snacks. I've learned to track everything more closely now, especially with the physical therapy and other unexpected costs. It's not always perfect, but I've come to see these fluctuations as part of life — not something to stress over, but something to plan for, even if it's just a little at a time.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family has grown and how I've come to rely on them in ways I never expected. Talking about my health struggles reminded me of how my family has stepped up — Tom has taken on more responsibilities, and the kids have learned to be more mindful of my needs. It's humbling to realize how much I depend on them, and how much they depend on me. It also made me think about how I don't use social media for emotional support, even though I know it's a tool that helps others. For me, support has always come from the people I know in real life, the ones who show up when it matters. I'm grateful for the ways my family has been there for me, and I hope to be that kind of support for them in return.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Anne Mullins: I do save, though it's not always in the most traditional way. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just a few dollars. But I also save in other ways — like buying secondhand clothes for the kids, fixing things around the house instead of replacing them, and meal planning to avoid wasting food. I remember growing up with so little, and I want to make sure my kids understand the value of saving, even if it's just a little at a time. There was a period when I wasn't saving much at all, and I realized how stressful it was not having a safety net. Now, I try to be more intentional about it, even if it's not a lot. It's not about having a huge amount — it's about knowing that I'm doing something for the future, even if it's just a small step forward.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Anne Mullins: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any specific big purchase. It's something I've come to realize is important, especially after dealing with my back injury and the unexpected costs that came with it. I don't have a huge emergency fund yet, but I try to set aside a little each month, even if it's just $50 or so. I also started using a budgeting app to track my expenses more closely, which has helped me see where I can cut back and where I need to be more careful. I think the biggest shift has been in my mindset — I used to think saving was something for the future, but now I see it as something I need to do every day, just like brushing my teeth or making time for the kids. It's not about having a lot, it's about being prepared, and I want my kids to grow up knowing that feeling of security, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Anne Mullins: I work as an accountant at a local firm, and my role involves managing financial records, preparing tax documents, and ensuring that everything is in order for our clients. The most important part of my job is making sure that people feel supported — whether it's helping a small business owner understand their finances or guiding someone through a complicated tax season. I've always found satisfaction in the precision of numbers and the way they tell a story about a person's or a company's financial health. What I love most is the challenge of solving problems — whether it's figuring out how to streamline a client's bookkeeping or finding a way to make things clearer for someone who's not as familiar with financial jargon. I started out as an assistant, and over the years, I've worked my way up to a senior accountant position. It's not the most exciting job in the world, but it's steady, and it allows me to be there for my family. I also do some freelance work on the side, mostly helping small businesses with their taxes during tax season. It's extra income, but it also keeps my skills sharp and gives me a sense of purpose outside of my regular job. I think what makes my job meaningful is knowing that I'm helping people in a way that's practical and tangible — it's not just about numbers, it's about making life a little easier for others.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Anne Mullins: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can vary a bit depending on the time of year. During tax season, I sometimes put in a few extra hours, especially with the freelance work I do on the side. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., and I try to leave on time so I can be there for the kids. I've always valued work-life balance, and I think that's something I learned growing up — seeing my mom work so hard and still find time to be there for us. Now, I make sure to leave work behind as much as I can, even if it means staying late one day so I can be present for another. It's not always perfect, but I've come to see that balance as one of the most important things I can offer my family — and it's something I hope my kids will understand as they grow up.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Anne Mullins: Yes, I did have more than one job at different points in my life, especially when I was in college and right after I graduated. While I was in school, I worked part-time at that local bookstore, which was how I met Tom. It wasn't much — just a few hours a week — but it helped me pay for books and groceries. After I got my degree, I took on a second job during tax season, helping small businesses with their filings. It was stressful, but it gave me extra income and kept me sharp. For a while, I was juggling my full-time job at the accounting firm with some freelance work on the side, especially during the busy months. It wasn't easy — there were days when I felt like I was running on empty — but it taught me the value of hard work and the importance of finding a balance. Now, I'm more selective about taking on extra work, but I still do some freelance projects when I can. It's not about making more money — it's about staying connected to the work I love and making sure I'm always growing, even in small ways.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in managing stress and understanding the importance of emotional support, both from my family and within myself. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come from the quiet girl at the kitchen table, learning to ask for help and practice mindfulness instead of pushing through everything alone. It also made me think about how my family has become my greatest source of strength — Tom's support, the kids' growing awareness of my needs, and the way we've all learned to lean on each other. I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned about balance, patience, and the value of being present, even when life feels overwhelming. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to take things one step at a time, knowing that I don't have to have all the answers — just the willingness to keep trying.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Anne Mullins: In total, our household made just over $6,000 last month. That includes my full-time salary from the accounting firm, Tom's income from his job at the local engineering company, and the extra income I brought in from freelance tax work. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our bills, save a little, and still have some room for things like groceries and the kids' activities. I've learned to be careful with money — not because I'm rich, but because I know how easily things can shift, especially with unexpected costs like medical bills or car repairs. I'm proud of how we've managed to keep things stable, even with all the changes in our lives. It's not about having more — it's about knowing that we're doing okay, and that we can keep going, even when things get a little tight.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Anne Mullins: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability it offers. The benefits are pretty standard — health insurance, dental and vision coverage, paid time off, and sick days. I think the health benefits have been especially important, especially after my back injury. Knowing that I can see a doctor or physical therapist without worrying about the cost has been a huge relief. The paid time off is something I used to take for granted, but now I realize how much it helps with work-life balance. I've taken a few weeks off for family vacations and even a couple of days for personal wellness — things like yoga retreats or just a weekend getaway with Tom. I think the best part of the job is that it allows me to be there for my family without sacrificing my own well-being. It's not a perfect job, but it's one that gives me the security I need to keep building the life I want for my kids and myself.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Anne Mullins: I would say my relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I've been lucky to have a manager who's supportive and understands the importance of balance — she's the one who encouraged me to take time off for my physical therapy and even offered flexible hours when I needed to adjust my schedule. I think she sees me as more than just an employee, which means a lot. As for my coworkers, we get along well — we're all pretty busy, but there's a sense of camaraderie, especially during tax season when we're all pulling together to meet deadlines. I've built some good friendships at work, and I think that makes the job more enjoyable. I've never been one for office politics or drama, so I'm grateful that my workplace feels like a place where I can be myself and focus on doing good work. It's not always perfect, but I feel like I'm in a good place here, and that matters a lot when you're spending so much of your time at work.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Anne Mullins: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which I actually appreciate — it gives me a sense of structure that helps me balance everything else in my life. I'm usually in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, and while there are occasional days when I have to stay late or come in early, especially during tax season, the core hours are pretty consistent. My manager has been great about offering some flexibility when needed, like allowing me to start a little later on days when I have doctor's appointments or when the kids have early morning activities. That flexibility has been a lifesaver, especially with my back injury and the need for regular physical therapy sessions. I think the predictability of the schedule helps me plan better for my family, and I'm grateful for that stability — it's one of the things that makes my job feel like a good fit for who I am and what I need in life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Anne Mullins: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation — not because I'm wealthy, but because I know we're doing okay and we've built a life that works for us. It's not always easy, especially with the unexpected costs that come up, like medical bills or car repairs, but I've learned to be resourceful and plan ahead as best as I can. I think the biggest thing is that I don't feel the pressure to have more than we need. We have a roof over our heads, food on the table, and the chance to give our kids the kind of childhood we never had. That feels like a win, even if it's not the kind of win you see on TV or in magazines. I know there are people out there with more, and there are people with less, but I'm grateful for what we have and the way we've managed to keep things stable. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that matters more than anything.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial life has evolved over the years, and how it continues to shape the way I think about stability, responsibility, and the future. Talking about our fluctuating bills reminded me of how much life can change from season to season — how a cold winter can add hundreds to the electricity bill, or how summer activities can add unexpected costs to our monthly budget. It also made me think about how I've learned to track our expenses more closely, not just to survive, but to thrive — to make sure we're not just getting by, but building something secure for my kids. I've come to see budgeting as more than just numbers on a spreadsheet; it's about making choices that reflect our values, our priorities, and our hopes for the future. And when I think about my job, my hours, and the way I balance work with family, I feel a deep sense of gratitude for the stability it provides. It's not about having everything — it's about knowing that we're doing okay, and that we can keep going, even when life throws us a curveball.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Anne Mullins: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up — in fact, she worked multiple jobs for most of my childhood. She was a part-time clerk at a local grocery store and also did some cleaning work for families in the neighborhood. It wasn't easy, especially after my father passed away, but she never let us go without. I remember her coming home exhausted after her second shift, sometimes with tears in her eyes, but she always made sure we had dinner on the table and that our homework was done. She never asked for help, not because she didn't need it, but because she was too proud — or maybe she just didn't know where to turn. Looking back, I wish I had realized how much she was sacrificing for us. It's one of the reasons I've always believed in the importance of education and hard work — not just for myself, but for the people I love. I want my kids to know that their mom and dad will always do what it takes to give them a better life, even if it means working long hours or making tough choices.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Anne Mullins: My mom worked as a part-time clerk at a local grocery store and also did cleaning work for families in our neighborhood. Her most important duties were making sure we had food on the table and that our homework was done, even when she was exhausted from her shifts. She was always meticulous about keeping the house clean and organized, and she had a way of making even the simplest meals feel like something special. I remember her working late into the night, sometimes folding laundry or doing the dishes while I was asleep, just so we wouldn't have to worry about anything the next day. She never complained, even when she was struggling — she just kept going, always putting our needs before her own. Looking back, I realize how much strength and sacrifice it took for her to do that, and it's one of the reasons I've always valued hard work and responsibility. I want my kids to know that their mom and dad will always do what it takes to give them a better life, even if it means working long hours or making tough choices.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Anne Mullins: My mom worked at a small, family-owned grocery store called 'Mullins Market' — it was actually owned by a relative of ours on my dad's side, which is why she got the job in the first place. The store wasn't very big, just a few aisles with basics like bread, milk, eggs, and canned goods. She was responsible for restocking shelves, checking inventory, and helping customers find what they needed. It wasn't glamorous work, but she took pride in making sure the store was always clean and well-organized. In the evenings, she'd do cleaning jobs for different families in our neighborhood — vacuuming, mopping, washing windows, and even doing some light gardening. She never made much money, but she always said that as long as we had food on the table and a roof over our heads, she was doing okay. Looking back, I realize how much she gave up for us, and it's one of the reasons I've always believed in the value of hard work and education. I want my kids to know that their mom and dad will always do what it takes to give them a better life, even if it means working long hours or making tough choices.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Anne Mullins: A few years from now, I hope I'm still here, still doing the things that bring me joy — like painting, walking with the kids, and sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee, watching the neighborhood kids play. I hope Liam is finding his way in the world, maybe studying something he's passionate about, and that Claire is still discovering who she is, whether that's through music, writing, or something else she loves. I hope we're still in this house, even if it's a little older, because it feels like home, and it's where so many of our memories are. I also hope I'm healthier, not just physically but mentally — that I'm still learning, growing, and finding ways to be present for the people I love. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with more gratitude, more connection, and more of those little moments that make life feel meaningful, even when it's not perfect.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Anne Mullins: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection — the people, the moments, and the little things that make life feel meaningful. I value my family above all else — Tom, Liam, Claire, and even my mom and brother, even when we don't see each other as often as I'd like. I value the resilience that has brought me here, the quiet strength of my mother, and the way she taught me that even in the hardest times, you can keep going. I value the community I live in, the neighbors who have been there for me, and the way this place has shaped me. I value the lessons I've learned through my health struggles — that it's okay to slow down, to ask for help, and to take care of myself so I can be there for the people I love. And I value the small, everyday moments — like the way my daughter laughs, the way my son talks about his dreams, or the way I can sit on the porch with a cup of coffee and feel like I'm exactly where I'm meant to be. Life isn't perfect, but these things — these connections, these lessons, these moments — are what make it worth living.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my financial life and work have shaped the stability and security I now have for my family. Talking about our household income, my job, and the benefits it provides reminded me of how far I've come from the girl who once sat at the kitchen table, watching my mom struggle to make ends meet. It's incredible to think that I now have a steady income, health benefits, and the flexibility to balance work with family, things I never took for granted growing up. I also realized how much my job has become more than just a source of income — it's a foundation for the life I want to build for my kids, one where they can feel secure and supported. It's not about having everything, but knowing that we're doing okay, and that we can keep going, even when life throws us a curveball. I'm grateful for the stability my job provides and for the lessons I've learned along the way about responsibility, resilience, and the importance of making choices that reflect our values and priorities.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, gratitude, and self-discovery. It's amazing to look back at the girl who sat at the kitchen table, watching her mother struggle, and see how that quiet determination has shaped the woman I am today. I've come to appreciate the strength it took to push through the challenges of growing up in a less-than-ideal situation, and I'm proud of the life I've built for myself and my family. This interview has reminded me of the power of resilience, the importance of community, and the value of small, consistent choices — whether it's in my health, my work, or my relationships. I've learned that life isn't about perfection, but about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding meaning in the everyday moments that make life feel deeply connected and meaningful. I'm grateful for the support I've received along the way and hope to pass that same sense of care and resilience on to my children and others in my community.
